description: A bearish reversal pattern forming after an uptrend, featuring two distinct peaks at similar price levels separated by a moderate low. Signals potential trend reversal from bullish to bearish.

structure: Two distinct peaks at approximately equal price levels (within 3-5% variance)
Peaks separated by clear valley (the 'middle low')
Time between peaks: ideally 4 weeks to 3 months on daily charts
Neckline drawn through the middle low support
Second peak should not significantly exceed first (creates 'M' shape)
volume: Volume typically higher on first peak
Volume should be lower on second peak (buying exhaustion)
Strong volume spike on neckline breakdown confirms pattern
Declining volume between peaks shows weakening momentum
indicators: RSI showing bearish divergence strongly validates (lower high while price makes equal high)
MACD bearish divergence (lower high on histogram)
Both peaks should occur in overbought territory (RSI >70)
Momentum decreasing on second peak compared to first
timeframe: Most reliable on weekly and daily charts
Can work on 4H for swing trades

invalidation_signals: Second peak significantly higher than first (>5% above) = new high, not reversal
Peaks too close together (<2 weeks on daily) = not true double top
Volume increasing on second peak = strong buying, pattern invalid
No bearish divergence on RSI/MACD = weak signal
Price breaks above second peak before neckline break
Forms in downtrend or sideways (needs prior uptrend)
common_mistakes: Calling any two peaks a double top without checking time separation
Ignoring volume - declining volume on second peak is critical
Not waiting for neckline break confirmation
Confusing with 'triple top' or 'head and shoulders'
Expecting perfect symmetry - peaks can vary slightly

trade_setup.entry: Enter short on break and close below neckline support
trade_setup.stop_loss: Place above second peak with small buffer (2-3%)
trade_setup.target: Measure peak-to-neckline distance, project same distance below neckline
